We hired a prostitute together and made her his wife, allowing him temporary enjoyment. But that prostitute saw that we were having a great time and fell asleep indulging ourselves. That prostitute chose our good things and ran away with them.
We are also here for the sake of this friend, and we have each brought our own offerings to seek out that courtesan in this forest.'
At that time, the Buddha told those people:
All you men!
I now ask you, what do you think?
Which is better, seeking for your own selves, or seeking for that courtesan? Which is more important?
Those men together replied to the Buddha:
Excellent!
World-Honored One!
If we now seek for our own selves, this is the most important, we should not seek for that woman.
At that time, the World-Honored One again said:
All good men!
If it is like this, you should sit at ease, I will now explain the Dharma for you.
At that time, those thirty male friends and companions together said to the Buddha:
Yes, World-Honored One!
One should not dare to go against the holy teachings.
At that time, those thirty friends bowed their heads at the Buddha's feet and sat to one side.

At that time, the World-Honored One spoke the Dharma for them in stages according to their capacities, speaking of giving, upholding precepts, practicing patience, and so forth, up to the characteristic of cessation of all dharmas. Having realized and known this as it truly is, like pure cloth without black threads, without stains, it immediately accepts the color according to what it is dyed with.

In this way, those thirty male friends, right there on their seats, distanced themselves from defilements, became free from stains, and immediately extinguished all afflictions. They attained the purity of the Dharma eye with regard to all dharmas, and knew through observation that all defiled dharmas are characterized by cessation.

At that time, those men, having seen the characteristics of dharmas in this way, attained the characteristics of dharmas, realized the characteristics of dharmas, entered the characteristics of dharmas, crossed over the characteristics of dharmas, eliminated doubts, were no longer confused or attached, reached the stage of fearlessness, and did not follow others' practices.
Having understood the World-Honored One's sacred teachings, they rose from their seats, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
'Excellent!
World-Honored One!
Please allow us to go forth and receive the precepts.'
At that time, the Buddha said to those men, 'Come, you men!
Enter the Dharma teachings I have spoken, practice the pure life, completely end the accumulation of suffering, and extinguish the edge of suffering.'
At that time, those elders immediately became monks, complete with precepts.
At that time, the World-Honored One further spoke the essentials of the Dharma for them, earnestly teaching them.

At that time, when the Buddha further taught them the Dharma, in a short time, that good man, with his right faith, left home to go forth, sought to complete the supreme pure conduct, and after attaining spiritual powers through his own realization, he declared with his own mouth:
I have now attained the fruits of the pure conduct, what was to be done has been done, and I will not again experience future existence. I know this to be so.
Those elders all became arhats with well-liberated minds.

At that time, the World-Honored One, having taught those thirty elder friends to attain realization, traveled through the country, passing through the White Blanket Grove. Having arrived at the grove, he went deep into the forest and saw a tree that was extremely beautiful. He sat under it for a day's rest.

At that time, there suddenly came sixty people of the Meghiya clan who passed by that forest path. Those people saw from afar the World-Honored One sitting under a tree, upright and pleasing, with a countenance that people delight in seeing, adorned like the stars in the sky.
Having seen this, their minds became pure and they gained right faith. With great joy, they went to where the Buddha was.
Having arrived, they bowed their heads at the Buddha's feet and then sat to one side. Having sat to one side, they remained silent.
At that time, the Buddha gradually taught the Dharma to those sixty people of the Meghiya clan, teaching them to practice giving and upholding precepts, and so forth.
Those elders all attained the fruit of arhatship and their minds were well liberated.
At that time, the World-Honored One had taught those sixty elders of the Meghiya clan to give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment. Having left them, he went to other places.
Sutra of the Collection of the Past Activities of the Buddha, Scroll 39
